Title: Fetchmail Client Buffer Overflow May Allow a Remote Mail Server to Execute Arbitrary Code on the Client System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in 'fetchmail'.  A malicious remote server could cause arbitrary code to be executed on the system running 'fetchmail'.
It is reported that the fetchmail client will trust data supplied by the remote server when retrieving mail from an IMAP server. The client allocates an array to store the sizes of the messages which it will attempt to download from the server and trusts the number of messages that the server claims to have.  

A malicious remote server could return an incorrect value causing the fetchmail process to write data outside of the allocated array boundary.  This could result in a denial of service condition or arbitrary code being executed on the fetchmail system.
Impact': A malicious remote IMAP server could cause the fetchmail client to crash or to execute arbitrary code when downloading messages from the mail server.  The code would run with the privileges of the 'fetchmail' process.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (5.9.10), available at:

http://www.tuxedo.org/~esr/fetchmail/

Title: NOCC PHP-based Webmail Client Software Displays Message Text as HTML Without Filtering, Allowing a Remote User to Access the Victim's Mailbox Using a Cross-Site Scripting Attack
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the NOCC web-mail client software.  A remote user can conduct a cross-site scripting attack against NOCC users to gain full access to their mailboxes.
ppp-design reported that the system will render mail messages as HTML without filtering the contents, even if the mail message is a text-based message.  A remote user can create an e-mail message that contains malicious scripting code and send it to a target (victim) user.  When the target user views the message via the NOCC application, the malicious code will be executed by the target user's browser.  The code will run in the security context of the site running NOCC and will be able to access the target user's cookies associated with that site.  As a result, the remote user can gain full access to the target user's mailbox.

The following is an example of message content that will trigger the vulnerability:

<script>alert(document.cookie)</script>
Impact': A remote user can cause arbitrary scripting code to run on a NOCC user's browser when the NOCC user views the message.  The code can gain full access to the NOCC user's e-mail account.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  According to the report, the vendor is working on a fix.

Title: Microsoft Outlook Weak Security Enforcement When Editing Messages with Microsoft Word Lets Remote Users Send Malicious Code to Outlook Recipients That Will Be Executed When Forwarded or Replied To
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Microsoft Outlook when Microsoft Word is used as the e-mail editor.  A remote user could cause arbitrary code to be executed.
Microsoft reported that Outlook 2000 and 2002 are vulnerable when configured with the option to use Microsoft Word as the e-mail editor when creating and editing e-mail in either Rich-Text or HTML formats.  This configuration is apparently referred to as "WordMail".

A remote user can send malicious mail to a target (victim) user so that when the target user replies to the mail or forwards the mail, arbitrary code is executed.  This is apparently possible because of a flaw in the security restrictions that the WordMail editor applies when Outlook is editing a message (as opposed to reading it).  Scripts are reportedly not blocked in this mode.  The arbitrary script that runs on the target user's computer would be able to take nearly any actions acting as that user.

The vendor reports that you are not affected if you do not use Word as the e-mail editor within Outlook.  Also, users of Office XP SP1 that have configured their system to read HTML mail as plain text are not vulnerable.
Impact': A remote user can send HTML or RTF-based e-mail to a target user to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target user's computer when the target user replies to or forwards the message.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.

For Microsoft Word 2002:

Client Installation:

http://office.microsoft.com/downloads/2002/wrd1003.aspx 

Administrative Installation: 
http://www.microsoft.com/office/ork/xp/journ/wrd1003a.htm 

For Microsoft Word 2000: 

Client Installation: 

http://office.microsoft.com/downloads/2002/wrd0901.aspx 

Administrative Installation: 

http://www.microsoft.com/office/ork/xp/journ/wrd0901a.htm 

This patch can reportedly be installed on systems running Office 2000 SR-1 or greater or Office XP SP-1 or greater. Microsoft plans to include this fix any future service packs for Microsoft Office.

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article #Q321804 shortly, to be available at the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://search.support.microsoft.com/kb/c.asp?SD=SO&LN=EN-US

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: /usr/bin/mail Application for Sun Solaris Lets Local Users Gain Privileges of the Mail Group
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the mail client application that lets local users obtain effective group id privileges of the "mail" group.
The vulnerability is reportedly due to a buffer overflow in SunOS 5.8 x86 with $HOME and /usr/bin/mail.

If the user's HOME environment variable is set to a lengthy string, the vulnerability can be triggered.  The following setting will reportedly trigger the vulnerability:

HOME=`perl -e 'print "A"x1100'` ; export HOME
mail a
CTL-C

A demonstration exploit script is included in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user can obtain group id privileges of the "mail" user group.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following fix:

SPARC 

     Solaris 2.5.1 with patch 109275-04 or later 
     Solaris 2.6 with patch 109266-04 or later 
     Solaris 7 with patch 109253-06 or later 
     Solaris 8 with patch 111874-05 or later 

Intel 

     Solaris 2.5.1 with patch 109276-04 or later 
     Solaris 2.6 with patch 109267-04 or later 
     Solaris 7 with patch 109254-06 or later 
     Solaris 8 with patch 111875-05 or later

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: Microsoft Outlook Express for Mac OS Has Buffer Overflow in Processing the 'file://' URL That Allows Remote Users to Cause Arbitrary Code to Be Executed
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description: A vulnerability has been reported in Microsoft Outlook Express for the Mac OS. A remote user can cause another user's Outlook Express mail client to execute arbitrary code. It is reported that Microsoft Outloox Express for the Mac OS does not properly handle lengthy subdirectories in the 'file://' directive, such as file:///AAAAAA[...] or file://A/A/A/A/[...]. A remote user can create HTML that includes a specially crafted 'file://' URL so that, when loaded by the target (victim) user, will cause arbitrary code to be executed by the target user's Outlook Express mail client. The code would run with the privileges of the target user. A demonstration exploit is provided below. This code will apparently overwrite the saved link register, used for a subroutine's return address on the PowerPC, with the value 0x41424344. According to the report, a remote user can supply up to 1313 characters of malicious code before the saved link register. In addition to the IMG SRC tag, the A HREF tag can apparently also be used. A working version of this demonstration exploit is available at: http://www.w00w00.org/files/advisories/ie_sample.html w00w00 credits Josha Bronson of Angry Packet Security on this discovery.
Impact': A remote user can create HTML that, when loaded by the target (victim) user, will cause arbitrary code to be executed by the target user's Microsoft Outlook Express with the privileges of the target user.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix.

The patches are available at:

http://www.microsoft.com/mac/download 

The patch for Microsoft Outlook Express 5.0.4 for Macintosh can be installed on systems running Mac OS 8 & 9. 

Microsoft plans to release Microsoft Knowledge Base article Q321309 regarding this vulnerability, to be available on the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://search.support.microsoft.com/kb/c.asp?SD=SO&LN=EN-US

Title: Microsoft Outlook Express for Mac OS Has Buffer Overflow in Processing the 'file://' URL That Allows Remote Users to Cause Arbitrary Code to Be Executed
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description: A vulnerability has been reported in Microsoft Outlook Express for the Mac OS. A remote user can cause another user's Outlook Express mail client to execute arbitrary code. It is reported that Microsoft Outloox Express for the Mac OS does not properly handle lengthy subdirectories in the 'file://' directive, such as file:///AAAAAA[...] or file://A/A/A/A/[...]. A remote user can create HTML that includes a specially crafted 'file://' URL so that, when loaded by the target (victim) user, will cause arbitrary code to be executed by the target user's Outlook Express mail client. The code would run with the privileges of the target user. A demonstration exploit is provided below. This code will apparently overwrite the saved link register, used for a subroutine's return address on the PowerPC, with the value 0x41424344. According to the report, a remote user can supply up to 1313 characters of malicious code before the saved link register. In addition to the IMG SRC tag, the A HREF tag can apparently also be used. A working version of this demonstration exploit is available at: http://www.w00w00.org/files/advisories/ie_sample.html w00w00 credits Josha Bronson of Angry Packet Security on this discovery.
Impact': A remote user can create HTML that, when loaded by the target (victim) user, will cause arbitrary code to be executed by the target user's Microsoft Outlook Express with the privileges of the target user.
Solution:
Microsoft has apparently developed a patch, reported to be available at:

http://www.microsoft.com/mac/download

Title: (Openbsd Issues Fix) OpenBSD '/usr/bin/mail' May Let Local Users Execute Commands With Root Privileges By Specifying a Malicious Crontab Entry
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in '/usr/bin/mail' on OpenBSD.  A local user that can specify a crontab entry may be able to cause arbitrary shell commands to be executed on the system with root level privileges.
It is reported that /usr/bin/mail allows a special escape sequence to be specified in the body of an email. This escape sequence specifies a shell comand to be executed, as described in the mail(1) man page:

~!command 

This tilde escape command is not supposed to be implemented for non-interactive mode.

A local user that can specify a cron file name may be able to cause arbitrary commands to be executed with root privileges when the cron job is run.
Impact': A local user that can specify cronttab entries may be able to cause arbitrary shell commands to be execute with root privileges, giving that user root level access to the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.

Patch for OpenBSD 3.0:

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/3.0/common/018_mail.patch

Patch for OpenBSD 2.9:

ftp://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/patches/2.9/common/023_mail.patch

Title: OpenBSD '/usr/bin/mail' May Let Local Users Execute Commands With Root Privileges By Specifying a Malicious Crontab Entry
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in '/usr/bin/mail' on OpenBSD.  A local user that can specify a crontab entry may be able to cause arbitrary shell commands to be executed on the system with root level privileges.
It is reported that /usr/bin/mail allows a special escape sequence to be specified in the body of an email.  This escape sequence specifies a shell comand to be executed, as described in the mail(1) man page:

~!command

A local user that can specify a cron file name may be able to cause arbitrary commands to be executed with root privileges when the cron job is run.

Demonstration exploit code is provided in the Source Message.

The author of the report credits urbanek@openbsd.cz for discovering vulnerability.
Impact': A local user that can specify cronttab entries may be able to cause arbitrary shell commands to be execute with root privileges, giving that user root level access to the system.
Solution:
The vendor has developed a patch, available at:

http://www.openbsd.org/cgi-bin/cvsweb/src/usr.bin/mail/collect.c.diff?r1=1.23&r2=1.24

Title: Symatec Computer 'popper_mod' PHP-based E-mail Client Default Configuration Allows Remote Users to Access the System's Administrative Pages
Description:
A configuration vulnerability was reported in the 'popper_mod' PHP-based POP3 e-mail client software.  A remote user can gain administrator access to the application in the default configuration.
It is reported that earlier versions of the product rely on the administrator to implement '.htaccess' authentication via the web server to protect the administration PHP script.  It is also reported that many administrators fail to do this, allowing a remote user to access the e-mail administrator pages using the following type of URL:

http://[targethost]/mail/admin
Impact': A remote user can gain access to the administrative pages without authentication in the default configuration.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (1.2.2 or higher), available at:

http://www.symatec-computer.com/forums/viewtopic.php?t=14

The new version requires the administrator to login to gain access rather than require on external htaccess authentication.

Title: (Sun Issues Fix) Re: Solaris Dtmail E-mail Client Buffer Overflow Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Group Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
NSFOCUS warned of a security vulnerability in the dtmail e-mail client for Sun Solaris that allows local users to obtain elevated group privileges.
The vulnerability is reportedly due to a buffer overflow in dtmail's processing of the MAIL environment variable.

Dtmail is apparently installed with set group id (setgid) privileges for the 'mail' group.

If a local user sets the MAIL environment variable to a character string that exceeds a certain length (for example, longer than 1500 bytes), the vulnerability will be triggered, potentially causing user-supplied arbitrary code to be executed with 'mail' group privileges.

It is reported that Solaris 2.6 with the following patches is not affected:
SunOS 5.6 SPARC :  105338-27
SunOS 5.6 x86   :  105339-25

It is reported that Solaris 7 with the following latest patches is still affected:
SunOS 5.7 SPARC :  107200-12
SunOS 5.7 x86   :  107201-12

It is reported that Solaris 8 is not affected.

The vendor reportedly has been notified.

An exploit transcript and a demonstration exploit script is provided in the Source Message.  The exploit script is also available at: http://www.nsfocus.com/proof/sol_sparc_dtmail_MAIL_ex.c
Impact': A local user can cause arbitrary code to be executed with 'mail' group privileges, giving the user 'mail' group access on the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix with the following patch versions:

For SPARC:

CDE 1.0.1 for Solaris 2.4 and 2.5 with patch 106920-02 or later 
CDE 1.0.2 for Solaris 2.4, 2.5 and 2.5.1 with patch 104178-04 or later 
CDE 1.2 for Solaris 2.6 with patch 105338-27 or later 

For Intel:

CDE 1.0.1 for Solaris 2.4 and 2.5 with patch 106921-02 or later 
CDE 1.0.2 for Solaris 2.4, 2.5 and 2.5.1 with patch 104185-04 or later 
CDE 1.2 for Solaris 2.6 with patch 105339-25 or later 

The vendor notes that a final solution is pending completion for Solaris 7. 

Note: Bug 4166321 was not completely fixed in Solaris 7. Patches 107200/107201 will address this in the next revision. The estimated target date is end-March 2002. 

The vendor has also described the following workaround:

Change the permissions for the CDE mailer (dtmail) using the following command as root: 

 # chmod 0555
/usr/dt/bin/dtmail                                                                 

Note: Changing the permissions of the CDE mailer may cause failures in reading NFS mounted mail spools. To read mail spools that are NFS mounted, remote login to the system and remote display the CDE mailer. 

The following is an example of how to do a remote display: 

 $ /usr/dt/bin/dtmail -display
mymachine:0                                   

Please see the Xserver(1) man page for more information.

Title: Instant Web Mail PHP-based Mail Client May Let Remote Users Cause Arbitrary POP Commands to Be Executed on Another User's Mail System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Instant Web Mail PHP-based POP3 mail client.  A remote user may be able to cause another user to load a link that will execute arbitrary POP commands on behalf of the user.
It is reported that the command() function, which is used to send a POP3 command to a POP3 server, allows user-supplied embedded CR and LF characters.  This allows the user to include additional POP3 commands in a user request.

It is also reported that the software converts URLs listed in e-mail messages into HTML links.  This may be used by a malicious user to send a malicious link that will redirect the target (victim) user from the malicious server to a page at the target user's Instant Web Mail site.  The malicious server can reportedly pass additional POP3 commands to, for example, delete mail.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[targethost]/instantwebmail/message.php?id=1%0D%0ADELE+2&
Impact': A remote user could send a malicous link to a target (victim) user that, when loaded by the target user, could cause arbitrary POP3 commands to be sent to the victim's mail system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version (0.60), available at:

http://understroem.dk/instantwebmail/instantwebmail.tar.bz2
http://understroem.dk/instantwebmail/instantwebmail.zip

Title: KMail E-mail Client Bug Lets Remote Users Send Large Messages to Cause the Client to Crash
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in KDE's KMail e-mail client.  The client may crash when attempting to read large mail messages.
It is reported that if an e-mail message body is about 55.x kbytes, the KMail client will crash.
Impact': A remote user can send a mail message of a certain size to cause the KMail client to crash when attempting to read the message.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: The Bat! E-mail Client MS-DOS Device Access Flaw Lets Remote Users Send Special E-mail to Cause the Recipient's E-mail Client to Crash
Description:
Security.NNOV issued an advisory warning of a denial of service vulnerability in 'The Bat!' e-mail client software.
It is reported that a remote user can send an e-mail message to a target (victim) user so that The Bat! will attempt to open a special MS-DOS device.  If The Bat! is configured to save attachments separately from message bodies, this vulnerability can be triggered.

A remote user can send a file that has the name of special MS-DOS device to cause the software to attempt to open that device.  This will reportedly cause the software to stop receiving any messages.  Sometimes a warning message is displayed and sometimes no warning is provided, according to the report.

The report indicates that it does not appear to be possible to cause the client to write to the device, but this has not been confirmed.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.

The following is a demonstration exploit transcript:

bash-2.03$ sendmail -U test@test.com
From: test
To: test
Content-Type: apllication/exe; name=lpt1

Test
.
Impact': A remote user can send a specially crafted e-mail message to a recipient that uses The Bat! e-mail client to cause the recipient's client to stop processing messages.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report indicates that, as a workaround, users can disable the "Keep   attachment files separately" option or use the "Account/Dispatch Mail On Server" option to delete problematic messages from the server.

Title: (Additional Details and Corrections are Provided) Re: Microsoft Outlook E-mail Client May Display Potentially Malicious File Attachments Illegally Embedded Within Mail Headers
Version(s): 5.5, 6.0; confirmed on Outlook Express 5.5 with Windows 95 and Outlook Express 6.0 on Windows 2000
Description:
A potential vulnerability was reported in Microsoft's Outlook e-mail client.  The software incorrectly interprets mail headers and may present header-embedded attachments that contain malicious code and have bypassed content scanning engines.
In the original report, it was reported that Outlook incorrectly interprets Carriage Returns (0x0d or <CR>) contained in SMTP mail headers as Carriage Return/Line Feed combinations (0x0d 0x0a or <CRLF>). As a result, an Outlook user may receive a message in which headers are incorrectly interpreted as message data. A user may be presented with attachments that do not exist (in accordance with RFC 822). It is reported that both UUencoded and MIME encoded attachments are affected by this bug. 

The author of the original report has clarified and corrected some details:

To hide a UUencoded attachment within the header so that Outlook will see the attachment reportedly requires a regular <CRLF> at the end of the UUencoded attachment.  So, the hidden attachment would look as follows:

X-some-header: <CR><CR>begin  hiding.txt<CR>.....uuencoding....<CR>....<CRLF>`<CR>end<CR>
Impact': A remote user may be able to send a mail message containing malicious code in the mail header such that the message will bypass content filtering software and yet still be displayed as an attachment when received by another user using Outlook.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Microsoft Outlook E-mail Client May Display Potentially Malicious File Attachments Illegally Embedded Within Mail Headers
Version(s): 5.5, 6.0; confirmed on Outlook Express 5.5 with Windows 95 and Outlook Express 6.0 on Windows 2000
Description:
A potential vulnerability was reported in Microsoft's Outlook e-mail client.  The software incorrectly interprets mail headers and may present header-embedded attachments that contain malicious code and have bypassed content scanning engines.
It is reported that Outlook incorrectly interprets Carriage Returns (0x0d or <CR>) contained in SMTP mail headers as Carriage Return/Line Feed combinations (0x0d 0x0a or <CRLF>).  As a result, an Outlook user may receive a message in which headers are incorrectly interpreted as message data.  A user may be presented with attachments that do not exist (in accordance with RFC 822).

It is reported that both UUencoded and MIME encoded attachments are affected by this bug.

An example of a UUencoded attachment is provided:

From: <001+outlookbug@nospam.blub.net>
To: <user@host>
Date: Tue, 14 Feb 2002 06:06:06 +0100
Subject: Valentine's Present!<CR><CR>begin  virus.exe<CR>M5F%L96YT:6IN(%-E<W-I;FL@+2!H='1P.B\O=W=W+F]P96YO9F9I8V4N;FPO<CR>end

It is reported that some content scanners will not see this as an attachment but Outlook will.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user may be able to send a mail message containing malicious code in the mail header such that the message will bypass content filtering software and yet still be displayed as an attachment when received by another user using Outlook.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Sun Solaris mail(1) Utility Lets Programs Pass Command Line Options to Sendmail that Could Give a Local or Remote User Elevated Privileges on the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Sun issued an alert warning of a vulnerability in mail.  A remote user may be able to gain elevated privileges on the system.
Sun reports that a vulnerability in mail(1) regarding the interaction of mail and sendmail(1M) may allow a privileged program to call mail and pass configuration options to sendmail.  This was reported earlier with in.lpd, where a remote usre could send data to the network print daemon to cause sendmail to be invoked with an alternate configuration file with root privileges (leading to remote root access).  According to Sun, in.lpd is the only privileged file that Sun ships that can use mail in an unsafe fashion.  However, Sun warns that there may be proprietary or 3rd party applications that use mail and could trigger this flaw.
Impact': A local or remote user could gain elevated privileges on the system.
Solution:
This vulnerability is reportedly fixed in the following releases:

SPARC 

     Solaris 2.5.1 with patch 109275-03 or later 
     Solaris 2.6 with patch 109266-03 or later 
     Solaris 7 with patch 109253-04 or later 
     Solaris 8 with patch 111874-04 or later 

Intel 

     Solaris 2.5.1 with patch 109276-03 or later 
     Solaris 2.6 with patch 109267-03 or later 
     Solaris 7 with patch 109254-04 or later 
     Solaris 8 with patch 111875-04 or later 

Sun notes that above patches address Bug ID 4502850 and most issues described in Sun Alert 41664, "Security Vulnerability with the in.lpd(1M) Daemon Allowing Options to be Passed to Sendmail". However, a final solution for Sun Alert 41664 is reported to be pending completion.
Underlying OS Comments: SPARC:  2.5.1 without patch 109275-03, 2.6 without patch 109266-03, 7 without patch 109253-04, 8 without patch 111874-04; Intel:

Title: (Caldera Issues Fix) Mutt E-mail Client Buffer Overflow May Let Remote Users Cause Arbitary Commands to Be Executed on the Mutt User's Host
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Mutt e-mail client that may allow remote users to cause arbitrary commands to be executed by another user's Mutt e-mail client.
It is reported that this vulnerability is remotely exploitable.  The bug is apparently due to a one byte buffer overflow.  No other details on the vulnerability were provided.
Impact': A remote user may be able to create an e-mail message that, when viewed by another user with the Mutt client, will cause arbitrary commands to be executed by the Mutt client with the privileges of the user running Mutt.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix) Pine E-mail Client Allows Remote Users to Send Malicious URLs Within a Message That Will Execute Arbitrary Shell Commands on the Recipient's Host When the URL is Loaded
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): 4.43 and prior versions for the vendor release
Description:
FreeBSD reported a vulnerability in the Pine e-mail client.  A remote user could send a mail message to another user containing a malicious URL that, if followed, could cause arbitrary shell commands to be executed on the recipient's host.
It is reported that Pine does not handle certain URLs in a secure manner.  A remote user can create and send a mail message containing a URL with certain meta-characters such that, if the recipient follows the URL link, will cause arbitrary shell commands to be passed by the recipient's Pine mail client as arguments to a call to the recipient's web browser.  Arbitrary shell commands will be executed on the recipient's host with the privileges of the recipient.

A remote user can reportedly supply commands enclosed in single quotes ('') in a URL embedded within an email message to exploit the vulnerability.  When the URL is loaded by the recipient, Pine will apparently launch a command shell and execute the remote user's commands with the privileges of the recipient.  It is reported that the malicious commands can be obfuscated so that the recipient may not be aware that the URL is malicious.

FreeBSD credits zen-parse with reporting this bug.
Impact': A remote user can cause arbitrary shell commands to be executed by a Pine user when the Pine user follows a URL link embedded within an email message sent by the remote user.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix and recommends that all users upgrade.

Title: Animecha Animation Mailer Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Cause Arbitrary Code to Be Executed on Another User's Host
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Shadow Penguin Security reported a buffer overflow vulnerability in Mitsubishi's Animecha animation mailer.  A remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed by the mail client.
It is reported that a remote user can send an e-mail attachment with a long file name to the mailer.  When the attachment is received, the buffer overflow can be triggered and arbitrary code may be executed on the recipient's host.

A demonstration exploit is available at:

http://www.shadowpenguin.org/sc_advisories/advisory043.html
Impact': A remote user can send an e-mail containing an attachment with a specially crafted file name to an Animecha user so that arbitrary code will be executed upon receipt by the Animecha user.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Engarde Issues Fix) Pine E-mail Client Allows Remote Users to Send Malicious URLs Within a Message That Will Execute Arbitrary Shell Commands on the Recipient's Host When the URL is Loaded
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): 4.43 and prior versions for the vendor release
Description:
FreeBSD reported a vulnerability in the Pine e-mail client.  A remote user could send a mail message to another user containing a malicious URL that, if followed, could cause arbitrary shell commands to be executed on the recipient's host.
It is reported that Pine does not handle certain URLs in a secure manner.  A remote user can create and send a mail message containing a URL with certain meta-characters such that, if the recipient follows the URL link, will cause arbitrary shell commands to be passed by the recipient's Pine mail client as arguments to a call to the recipient's web browser.  Arbitrary shell commands will be executed on the recipient's host with the privileges of the recipient.

A remote user can reportedly supply commands enclosed in single quotes ('') in a URL embedded within an email message to exploit the vulnerability.  When the URL is loaded by the recipient, Pine will apparently launch a command shell and execute the remote user's commands with the privileges of the recipient.  It is reported that the malicious commands can be obfuscated so that the recipient may not be aware that the URL is malicious.

FreeBSD credits zen-parse with reporting this bug.
Impact': A remote user can cause arbitrary shell commands to be executed by a Pine user when the Pine user follows a URL link embedded within an email message sent by the remote user.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  Registered users of the EnGarde Secure Linux Professional edition can use the Guardian Digital Secure Network to upgrade their packages automatically.

  All updates may be found at:

    ftp://ftp.engardelinux.org/pub/engarde/stable/updates/
    http://ftp.engardelinux.org/pub/engarde/stable/updates/

  Before upgrading the package, the machine must either:

    a) be booted into a "standard" kernel; or
    b) have LIDS disabled.

  To disable LIDS, execute the command:

    # /sbin/lidsadm -S -- -LIDS_GLOBAL

  To install the updated package, execute the command:

    # rpm -Uvh <filename>

  You must now update the LIDS configuration by executing the command:

    # /usr/sbin/config_lids.pl

  To re-enable LIDS (if it was disabled), execute the command:

    # /sbin/lidsadm -S -- +LIDS_GLOBAL

  To verify the signatures of the updated packages, execute the command:

    # rpm -Kv <filename>

  These updated packages are for EnGarde Secure Linux 1.0.1 (Finestra).

  Source Packages:

    SRPMS/pine-4.33-1.0.6.src.rpm
      MD5 Sum: 7a6653d8814945edee9ab544afb696bc

  Binary Packages:

      MD5 Sum: 4b1d60e1e7ccb3a8a511db42877f0b15

    i686/pine-4.33-1.0.6.i686.rpm

    1. If you use the tripwire product, we recommend that you run a 
       a consistency check and fix any violations before installing

    2. Install the advisory RPM from the root account.

           rpm -F <advisory RPM name>

    3. Update the tripwire database

           tripwire --check --interactive

Title: (Additional Exploit Details Are Provided) Re: Pine E-mail Client Allows Remote Users to Send Malicious URLs Within a Message That Will Execute Arbitrary Shell Commands on the Recipient's Host When the URL is Loaded
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): 4.43 and prior versions for the vendor release
Description:
FreeBSD reported a vulnerability in the Pine e-mail client.  A remote user could send a mail message to another user containing a malicious URL that, if followed, could cause arbitrary shell commands to be executed on the recipient's host.
It is reported that Pine does not handle certain URLs in a secure manner. A remote user can create and send a mail message containing a URL with certain meta-characters such that, if the recipient follows the URL link, will cause arbitrary shell commands to be passed by the recipient's Pine mail client as arguments to a call to the recipient's web browser. Arbitrary shell commands will be executed on the recipient's host with the privileges of the recipient. A remote user can reportedly supply commands enclosed in single quotes ('') in a URL embedded within an email message to exploit the vulnerability. When the URL is loaded by the recipient, Pine will apparently launch a command shell and execute the remote user's commands with the privileges of the recipient. It is reported that the malicious commands can be obfuscated so that the recipient may not be aware that the URL is malicious.

If a local user selects the following type of URL from within a Pine e-mail message, a program (/some/program) will be executed with arguments supplied to the program:

  http://address/'&/some/program${IFS}with${IFS}arguments&'
Impact': A remote user can cause arbitrary shell commands to be executed by a Pine user when the Pine user follows a URL link embedded within an email message sent by the remote user.
Solution:
For FreeBSD users, a fixed version is available (see the information below).

For other (non-FreeBSD) users, a fixed version (4.44) is available at the Vendor URL.

For FreeBSD users, the following solution is provided:

1) Upgrade your entire ports collection and rebuild the port.

2) Deinstall the old package and install a new package dated after the correction date, obtained from the following directories:

[i386]
ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/ports/i386/packages-4-stable/mail/pine-4.44.tgz
ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/ports/i386/packages-5-current/mail/pine-4.44.tgz

[alpha]
Packages are not automatically generated for the alpha architecture at this time due to lack of build resources.

3) Download a new port skeleton for the pine port from:

http://www.freebsd.org/ports/

and use it to rebuild the port.

4) Use the portcheckout utility to automate option (3) above. The portcheckout port is available in /usr/ports/devel/portcheckout or the package can be obtained from:

ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/ports/i386/packages-4-stable/devel/portcheckout-2.0.tgz
ftp://ftp.FreeBSD.org/pub/FreeBSD/ports/i386/packages-5-current/devel/portcheckout-2.0.tgz

      MD5 checksum: b206557565607833551219ff67737cd4

  ARM architecture:
    http://security.debian.org/dists/stable/updates/main/binary-arm/mutt_1.2.5-5_arm.deb
      MD5 checksum: 57c0c2602c3bfde3f459f01515432eac

  Intel IA-32 architecture:
    http://security.debian.org/dists/stable/updates/main/binary-i386/mutt_1.2.5-5_i386.deb
      MD5 checksum: d72fa58b0914762674648a68d410b4b9

  Motorola 680x0 architecture:
    http://security.debian.org/dists/stable/updates/main/binary-m68k/mutt_1.2.5-5_m68k.deb
      MD5 checksum: 266c451cee06693e7f40917b0465981a

  PowerPC architecture:
    http://security.debian.org/dists/stable/updates/main/binary-powerpc/mutt_1.2.5-5_powerpc.deb
      MD5 checksum: aec60dae6148ac9da29c111e70ea77b0

These packages will be moved into the stable distribution on its next revision.

For not yet released architectures please refer to the appropriate directory ftp://ftp.debian.org/debian/dists/sid/binary-$arch/

See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to apply the appropriate fix.

Title: Mutt E-mail Client Buffer Overflow May Let Remote Users Cause Arbitary Commands to Be Executed on the Mutt User's Host
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Mutt e-mail client that may allow remote users to cause arbitrary commands to be executed by another user's Mutt e-mail client.
It is reported that this vulnerability is remotely exploitable.  The bug is apparently due to a one byte buffer overflow.  No other details on the vulnerability were provided.
Impact': A remote user may be able to create an e-mail message that, when viewed by another user with the Mutt client, will cause arbitrary commands to be executed by the Mutt client with the privileges of the user running Mutt.
Solution: mutt-1.2.5.1 and mutt-1.3.25 have been released to correct the problem.  They are available at the Vendor URL or http://www.mutt.org/

Title: Outlook Express for Macintosh May Crash While Downloading POP3 Mail Containing a Long Line
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Microsoft's Outlook Express e-mail client for the Macintosh platform.  A remote user can send e-mail containing a long line that will cause the recipients's Outlook Express mail client to crash when downloading the message via POP3.
A copy of a message that will trigger the vulnerability is available at:

http://www.securityfocus.com/archive/1/199251
Impact': A remote user could cause another user's Outlook Express for Macintosh e-mail client to crash while downloading messages from a POP3 server.
Solution: It is reported that Microsoft has released a fix in version 5.03 (English version).

Title: Outlook Express Secure Password Authentication Method is Vulnerable to Man-in-the-Middle Attacks
Description:
SECURITY.NNOV warned of security issues with Microsoft Outlook Express's Secure Password Authentication feature.
Outlook Express apparently offers a Secure Password Authentication (SPA) option for authenticating a remote client to a POP3/IMAP/SMTP server without sending a cleartext password over the network.

It is reported that SPA is based on NTLM v.1, which is known to be vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks.  If a remote user can impersonate a mail server, the remote user can authenticate to the mail server with the remote client's credentials or to other servers that support NTLMv1 authentication.  The remote client may be tricked into thinking it is authenticated by a valid mail server.

It is reported that when SPA is used for POP3 access (for example) account in Outlook Express, the remote Outlook Express client does not use the POP3 username/password provided in the POP3 transaction.  Instead, it attempts to connect to the POP3 server with the user's Windows  NT domain logon credentials.  If this fails, Outlook Express reportedly requests the user's username/password information and stores this in the users's password list.  This single username/password will apparently be used for all Outlook Express accounts on the same server.  It is reported that a malicious server (or man-in-the-middle) can cause some "AUTH NTLM" challenge/response exchanges to occur during a remote client's authentication attempt without prompting the remote user.  This gives the man-in-the-middle the opportunity to connect to several password-protected resources using the remote user's credentials.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A user can conduct a man-in-the-middle attack on Outlook Express clients (when configured for SPA authentication) and potentially gain access to other password-protected resources using the client's credentials.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the report recommends not using SPA to connect to hosts if those hosts are not Exchange servers located in the user's domain.

Title: (Sun Provides Patch) Re: Mailx Client for Sun Solaris Allows Local Users to Execute Code with Mail Group Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Solaris mailx(1) client, allowing a local user to execute arbitrary code on the host with mail group privileges.
There is reportedly a buffer overflow vulnerability using the mailx -F option.  By specifying a long buffer containing machine executable code, it is possible for a local user to trigger the vulnerablity and cause an arbitrary command to be executed.  Because the mailx program is installed set group id mail by default in Solaris, this arbitrary code can be executed with mail group privileges.

The following packages/systems are reported to be vulnerable.

Solaris 8     SPARC
Solaris 8     x86
Solaris 7     SPARC
Solaris 7     x86
Solaris 2.6   SPARC
Solaris 2.6   x86
Solaris 2.5.1 SPARC
Solaris 2.5.1 x86
Solaris 2.5   SPARC
Solaris 2.5   x86

The vendor has reportedly been notified.

Some demonstration exploit code is contained in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can cause arbitrary code to be executed on the host with the mail group privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has released a patch.  The following versions are not vulnerable:

SPARC 

     Solaris 2.5 with patch 112061-02 or later 
     Solaris 2.5.1 with patch 112086-02 or later 
     Solaris 2.6 with patch 112073-02 or later 
     Solaris 7 with patch 107441-03 or later 
     Solaris 8 with patch 110957-02 or later 

Intel 

     Solaris 2.5 with patch 112062-02 or later 
     Solaris 2.5.1 with patch 112087-02 or later 
     Solaris 2.6 with patch 112074-02 or later 
     Solaris 7 with patch 107442-03 or later 
     Solaris 8 with patch 110958-02 or later

Title: NeoMail Web-based Mail Client Package for Sun Cobalt RaQ and Cube Appliances Contains Suidperl Vulnerability That Lets Remote Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Sun reports that there is a security vulnerability in the NeoMail package for their RaQ and Cube appliances.  The flaw is due to the use of the vulnerable suidperl utility, which allows a local user to execute commands with root privileges.
It is reported that Cobalt RaQ and Cube NeoMail package versions 1.25-1 to 1.25-3 are vulnerable due to the activation of the suidperl utility in that package.  NeoMail itself is not vulnerable, but suidperl is.  A local user can cause arbitrary commands to be executed with root level privileges, giving the local user root level access on the Cobalt host.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code with root level privileges and gain root level access.
Solution:
Upgrade to package version 1.25-5, available at the Vendor URL:

http://pkg.nl.cobalt.com/

Sun recommends that all users who downloaded the NeoMail package before November 14, 2001 should replace NeoMail with the new version.
Underlying OS Comments: Affects only Sun Cobalt (RaQ and Cube) packages

Title: (A User Provides a Solution) Re: Lotus Notes E-mail Client Automatically Executes Arbitrary LotusScript Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): Lotus Notes Client 5 All releases Lotus Notes Client 4.6 All releases
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Lotus Notes.  A remote user can send an e-mail that will cause arbitrary LotusScript code to be executed when a recipient views or previews the e-mail.
It is reported that Lotus Notes will automatically execute LotusScript when an e-mail containing the code is viewed or previewed.

The steps to demonstrate this vulnerability are included in the Source Message.
Impact':
A remote user on a Notes domain can send an e-mail containing scripting code to a target user within an interconnected Notes domain such that the code will be automatically executed when the recipient views or previews the message.  The code can take any action on behalf of the recipient.

It is reported that the SMTP gateway does not pass LotusScript, so the remote user must be on an interconnected Notes domain.
Solution:
A user reports that an Execution Control List (ECL), which is available in both R4.6x and R5.x, can be used to prevent this vulnerability.

Lotus has reportedly published an article (April 2001) regarding this issue:

http://www.lotus.com/home.nsf/welcome/securityzone

Select "Lotus Notes Stored Form Vulnerability."

Title: Hotmail E-mail Service Allows Malicious Javascript to be Passed via the HTML Image Tag and Executed on the User's Browser
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description: A Javascript filtering vulnerability was reported in Microsoft's Hotmail e-mail service. A remote user could pass malicious Javascript to the user's browser where it may be executed. It is reported that a remote user can bypass the Hotmail Javascript filtering system using the .. tag with the following type of format: In this case, the src="javascript:bla" is changed to src="javascript:Filtered()" and so the Javascript is not executed. However, the second image-background is not filtered: url('javascript:alert%28test%29') A demonstration exploit is described in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can exploit this vulnerability to access cookies, URLs, and personal information and to redirect pages.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Lotus Notes E-mail Client Automatically Executes Arbitrary LotusScript Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): Lotus Notes Client 5 All releases Lotus Notes Client 4.6 All releases
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Lotus Notes.  A remote user can send an e-mail that will cause arbitrary LotusScript code to be executed when a recipient views or previews the e-mail.
It is reported that Lotus Notes will automatically execute LotusScript when an e-mail containing the code is viewed or previewed.

The steps to demonstrate this vulnerability are included in the Source Message.
Impact':
A remote user on a Notes domain can send an e-mail containing scripting code to a target user within an interconnected Notes domain such that the code will be automatically executed when the recipient views or previews the message.  The code can take any action on behalf of the recipient.

It is reported that the SMTP gateway does not pass LotusScript, so the remote user must be on an interconnected Notes domain.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Apple's Claris Emailer Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Crash the E-mail Client and May Allow Arbitrary Code to be Executed
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): Claris Emailer-J 2.0v1 (Japanese version); may also affect 2.0v2
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Apple's Claris Emailer mail client software.  A remote user could send a special e-mail to another user to cause the mail client to crash or possibly cause arbitrary code to be executed by the recipient's Claris Emailer.
It is reported that the Claris Emailer does not properly handle long file names for attachments and, when processing such a message, a buffer overflow will occur.

It is also reported that when a user receives a malicious message, the email client will crash and will not work properly util the recipient revises or removes a temporary file created by the email client for the malicious message.  Arbitrary code execution may be possible.
Impact': A remote user could create a specially crafted e-mail that will cause the recipient's email client to crash or possibly to execute arbitrary code.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Microsoft Outlook Express Will Execute Active Scripting in Plain Text E-mail Messages, Circumventing Some Scripting Controls
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
It is reported that Microsoft's Outlook Express will execute Active Scripting that is embedded within a plain text e-mail message.  Normally, active scripting would be contained in an HTML message.
For example, the following plain text message will cause the embedded script to be execute by the recpient's mail reader:

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
 charset="Windows-1252"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2600.0000
X-MIMEOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2600.0000
X-Source: 11.09.01  http://www.malware.com

<script>alert("freak");alert("show")</script>

This security implementation flaw may be of concern in networks that filter or block active content in HTML-based messages (those with Content-Type: text/html MIME headers).

It is reported that only the <script> tag will be parsed and executed and that other tags (e.g., <IFRAME>, <OBJECT>) are treated properly (as plain text).

The report notes that active scripting is not configured by default in Outlook Express 6.00. 

A demonstration exploit example is provided at the following URL:

http://www.malware.com/malware.zip
Impact': A remote user can craft a plain text (RFC822) e-mail message that contains malicious active scripting code that will bypass some active code filters and be executed by the recipients Outlook Express mail reader.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.
Underlying OS Comments: Tested on Windows 98 and RTM Build of Windows XP

Title: Hotmail Web E-mail Service Allows Remote Users to Cause Malicious Javascript to be Executed by the Recipient's Browser, Potentially Stealing Authentication Cookies
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A Javascript filtering vulnerability was reported in Microsoft's Hotmail e-mail service.  A remote user can craft an e-mail that contains malicious Javascript that may be executed automatically by the recipient's browser, potentially sending the recipient's Hotmail authentication cookies to the remote user.
It is reported that a remote user can embed Javascript in the 'from' address field, which Hotmail apparently does not filter:

"a background=javascript:alert('test') @hotmail.com" (without quotes)

Then, when the recipient uses Hotmail, the Javascript may be executed by the recipient's browser, as Hotmail will render the from address as HTML for the name of an HTML table cell for the message link:

<td name=""a background=javascript:alert('test') "@hotmail.com">

Some demonstration code examples are included in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can send malicious Javascript to Hotmail users that may be executed by the recipient's browser.  The malicious code could obtain the user's Hotmail authentication cookies and forward it.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Msgchk Message Checking Utility for MH Mail Handler System Lets Local Users Execute Arbitary Code to Gain Root Level Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the 'msgchk' messag checking utility for the MH mail system that could allow a local user to execute arbitrary code with root level privileges and gain root level access to the system.  A second flaw lets local users read a line from any file on the system.
It is reported that /usr/bin/mh/msgchk has a buffer overflow that can be triggered with a long string as a command line argument. This allows a local user to specify shell code that will be executed with root level privileges.

Another vulnerability allows a local user to read one line of any file on the system.  It is reported that msgchk will follow symbolic links.  A local user can create a symlink from their own ~/.mh_profile file to any file on the system.  When the user then executes msgchk, one line from the linked file will be displayed.

Demonstration exploit code for both vulnerabilities is included in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code on the system with root level privileges, gaining root level access on the system.  A local user can read one line of any file on the system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.
Underlying OS Comments: Reported on Digital Unix 4.0x, may or may not apply to other operating systems

Title: (Conectiva Issues Fix) KDE KMail E-mail Client May Corrupt Mail Folders Due to UNIX Date Rollover
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in some versions of KDE KMail.  Older versions will fail to work properly on and after September 9, 2001 when a number overflow will cause KMail mail folders to be corrupted.
This vulnerability is due to the UNIX time rollover (where one billion seconds will have passed since the beginning of the UNIX epoch at 00:00 on 1 January 1970).
Impact': Mail and mail folders may be corrupted and or mail dates will be incorrect.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.

Title: Microsoft Outlook 2000 Animated Assistant Prevents the Screen Saver from Activating, Allowing Physically Local Users to Access the System
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Microsoft Outlook 2000 in the Animated Assistant feature.  The feature prevents the activation of the screen saver, allowing physically local users to access the system when the system is unattended for a period of time.
It is reported that there is a problem in the Windows operating system inactivity mechanism when Outlook 2000's Animated Assistant is enabled.
Impact': A physically local user can gain access to the system when it is unattended.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.

As a workaround, the report recommends locking the workstation manually via: CTRL-ALT-DEL and clicking on 'Lock.'

Title: KDE KMail E-mail Client May Corrupt Mail Folders Due to UNIX Date Rollover
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in some versions of KDE KMail.  Older versions will fail to work properly on and after September 9, 2001 when a number overflow will cause KMail mail folders to be corrupted.
This vulnerability is due to the UNIX time rollover (where one billion seconds will have passed since the beginning of the UNIX epoch at 00:00 on 1 January 1970).
Impact': Mail and mail folders may be corrupted and or mail dates will be incorrect.
Solution: The vendor recommends that users update to KDE 2.2, which includes KMail 1.3.  See the Vendor URL for details.

Title: Outlook Express Lets Remote Users Send Malicious Attachments That Will Bypass Security Features
Description:
A security flaw was reported in Microsoft's Outlook Express 6.00 e-mail client.  With new file attachment security features enabled, a remote user can send a malicious executable attachment
A remote user can embed a malicious executable file within an HTML frame that is Base64 encoded:

<frameset rows="100%,*">
<frame src="malware.exe">
</frameset>

When this e-mail is received by the target (victim), the user will be asked for input as to the disposition of this message, even if the user has selected the new security option ("do not allow attachments to be saved or opened that could potentially be a virus").

It the remote user renames the *.exe file to a batch file (*.bat), and sends it in a "message/rfc822" MIME type, the file will be executed when the recipient clicks "open it."  The recipient may be enticed to execute the file if it has an innocuous file name.
Impact': A remote user can craft an e-mail message that will circumvent Outlook Express's new security features.  A target victim may be tricked into executing an attachment even when the security features are enabled.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Microsoft Issues Updated Fix) Microsoft Outlook Allows Rogue HTML to Execute Arbitrary Commands on the User's Host
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Georgi Guninski issued an advisory for Microsoft Outlook (part of Office XP), warning that it allows a web page or HTML-based e-mail message to cause arbitrary commands to be executed on the user's host.
The vulnerability is reportedly due to a vulnerable ActiveX control "Microsoft Outlook View Control" that is apparently installed by Outlook.  This control reportedly exposes a property named "selection", which gives access to the user's mail messages, and the Outlook "Application" object, which allows commands to be executed on the user's host.
Impact': A web page or HTML-based e-mail message could cause arbitrary commands to be executed on the user's host with the privileges of the user.  This could also cause the user's e-mail to be viewed, modified, and/or deleted.
Solution: The vendor has released an update fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.

Title: (Mandrake Issues Fix) Elm E-mail Client Lets Mail from Remote Users Overwrite Other Elm E-mail Display Fields
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the elm e-mail client that allowed remote users to cause the client to display incorrect information.
It is reported that e-mail messages with a long Message-ID header will trigger a buffer overflow in the elm e-mail client.  Part of a long Message-ID header may overwrite the "date" field in the elm message list with a longer string than normally appears there, which will cause the line to wrap and alter the remainder of the display screen.

It is reportedly possible that the buffer overflow could modify other fields.
Impact': A remote user can craft an e-mail message with a long Message-ID header that can cause the elm client to display incorrect information.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.

Title: Solaris Dtmail E-mail Client Buffer Overflow Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Group Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): Sun Solaris 2.6 (SPARC/x86), Sun Solaris 7 (SPARC/x86); (Sun Solaris 8 is reportedly not affected)
Description:
NSFOCUS warned of a security vulnerability in the dtmail e-mail client for Sun Solaris that allows local users to obtain elevated group privileges.
The vulnerability is reportedly due to a buffer overflow in dtmail's processing of the MAIL environment variable.

Dtmail is apparently installed with set group id (setgid) privileges for the 'mail' group.

If a local user sets the MAIL environment variable to a character string that exceeds a certain length (for example, longer than 1500 bytes), the vulnerability will be triggered, potentially causing user-supplied arbitrary code to be executed with 'mail' group privileges.

It is reported that Solaris 2.6 with the following patches is not affected:
SunOS 5.6 SPARC :  105338-27
SunOS 5.6 x86   :  105339-25

It is reported that Solaris 7 with the following latest patches is still affected:
SunOS 5.7 SPARC :  107200-12
SunOS 5.7 x86   :  107201-12

It is reported that Solaris 8 is not affected.

The vendor reportedly has been notified.

An exploit transcript and a demonstration exploit script is provided in the Source Message.  The exploit script is also available at: http://www.nsfocus.com/proof/sol_sparc_dtmail_MAIL_ex.c
Impact': A local user can cause arbitrary code to be executed with 'mail' group privileges, giving the user 'mail' group access on the system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Elm E-mail Client Lets Mail from Remote Users Overwrite Other Elm E-mail Display Fields
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the elm e-mail client that allowed remote users to cause the client to display incorrect information.
It is reported that e-mail messages with a long Message-ID header will trigger a buffer overflow in the elm e-mail client.  Part of a long Message-ID header may overwrite the "date" field in the elm message list with a longer string than normally appears there, which will cause the line to wrap and alter the remainder of the display screen.

It is reportedly possible that the buffer overflow could modify other fields.
Impact': A remote user can craft an e-mail message with a long Message-ID header that can cause the elm client to display incorrect information.
Solution: Red Hat has released new elm packages for Red Hat Linux 5.2, 6.2, 7 and 7.1.

Title: (Microsoft Issues Fix) Microsoft Outlook Allows Rogue HTML to Execute Arbitrary Commands on the User's Host
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Georgi Guninski issued an advisory for Microsoft Outlook (part of Office XP), warning that it allows a web page or HTML-based e-mail message to cause arbitrary commands to be executed on the user's host.
The vulnerability is reportedly due to a vulnerable ActiveX control "Microsoft Outlook View Control" that is apparently installed by Outlook.  This control reportedly exposes a property named "selection", which gives access to the user's mail messages, and the Outlook "Application" object, which allows commands to be executed on the user's host.
Impact': A web page or HTML-based e-mail message could cause arbitrary commands to be executed on the user's host with the privileges of the user.  This could also cause the user's e-mail to be viewed, modified, and/or deleted.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Vendor URL for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.

Title: Microsoft Outlook Allows Rogue HTML to Execute Arbitrary Commands on the User's Host
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Georgi Guninski issued an advisory for Microsoft Outlook (part of Office XP), warning that it allows a web page or HTML-based e-mail message to cause arbitrary commands to be executed on the user's host.
The vulnerability is reportedly due to a vulnerable ActiveX control "Microsoft Outlook View Control" that is apparently installed by Outlook.  This control reportedly exposes a property named "selection", which gives access to the user's mail messages, and the Outlook "Application" object, which allows commands to be executed on the user's host.
Impact': A web page or HTML-based e-mail message could cause arbitrary commands to be executed on the user's host with the privileges of the user.  This could also cause the user's e-mail to be viewed, modified, and/or deleted.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Lmail E-mail Client Gives Local Users Root Level Access
Description:
A vulnerability has been discovered in the lmail e-mail client that allows local users to create files or overwrite existing files on the host with root level privileges, giving root level access to the local user.
lmail reportedly contains an insecure mktemp() race condition that allows a local user to overwrite or create files.  A local user can create a symbolic link from the temporary file that lmail uses to any other file on the system and then can write contents to this temporary file (which is symlinked to another file).  Because lmail is installed with set user id (suid) root privileges, the local user can write to any file on the system.

The offending code is reportedly contained in lmail.c [Editor's note:  All the code is in lmail.c]:

#define MAIL_TMPFILE    "/tmp/rmXXXXXX"

...

static char     tempfname[] = MAIL_TMPFILE;

...

if (fseek(stdin, 0L, 0) != 0) {
        mailfile = fopen(mktemp(tempfname), "w+");
...


Demonstration exploit code is available at:

http://www.ezlink.com/~core/hot/lmail-xpl.c
Impact': A local user can write to or create any file on the host with root level privileges.  This allows the local user to obtain root level access on the host.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the report provides a suggested patch (see the Source Message).

Title: (Information on Vulnerable Versions) Re: /usr/bin/mail Application for Sun Solaris Lets Local Users Gain Privileges of the Mail Group
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the mail client application that lets local users obtain effective group id privileges of the "mail" group.
A user reports that Solaris 7/Sparc is vulnerable and provides the following exploit transcript:

"[gwolf@sun gwolf]$ uname -a
SunOS sun.mydomain.org 5.7 Generic_106541-16 sun4u sparc SUNW,Ultra-5_10
[gwolf@sun gwolf]$ HOME=`perl -e 'print "A"x1100'` ; export HOME
[gwolf@sun gwolf]$ mail a
^Cmail: ERROR signal 10
mail: ERROR signal 10
mail: ERROR signal 10
mail: ERROR signal 10
mail: ERROR signal 10
(...)"

For details on the vulnerability, see the Message History.
Impact': A local user can obtain group id privileges of the "mail" user group.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.
Underlying OS Comments: SunOS 5.8 x86; other operating systems not tested

Title: Microsoft Outlook Express May Allow A Remote User to Obtain E-mail Destined for a Different User
Description:
SECURITY.NNOV has reported a vulnerability in the Microsoft Outlook Express e-mail client that may allow a remote user to obtain e-mail destined for a different user.
Outlook Express reportedly includes an option "Automatically put people I reply to in my address  book" that will cause Outlook Express to automatically add a received message's address to the address book, mapping the Name of the sender to the address of the sender.

This allows a remote user to cause a bogus address to be entered into the recipient's address book and mapped to a non-bogus Name.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user may be able to enter a bogus e-mail address into the Outlook Express user's address book that maps to a non-bogus Name such that when the Outlook Express user chooses to send valid mail to the valid Name, the e-mail will instead be delivered to the bogus address.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Netscape Messenger E-mail Client Discloses Some User Information to Remote Web Sites
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in Netscape Messenger that allows a remote user to obtain certain information about a user and their Netscape installation.
The vulnerability is due to Netscape Messanger 's use of an internal mailbox URI of the following format:  mailbox://full_path_to_user_folder?ID=some_message_d&number=some number

This URI  reportedly contains the full path to user's mailbox, which typically includes the user's login name and, for Windows 9x platforms, the path to Netscape
installation.

A Javascript application can reportedly retrieve the mailbox:// URI of the message.  When a link is activated (clicked) from within an e-mail message, Netscape Messenger sets the "document.referrer" property to the URI of the e-mail message.

A demonstration exploit page is available at: http://www.security.nnov.ru/files/nsdemo.asp

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can potentially obtain a user's Netscape e-mail name (which may also be the user's Windows login name), mailbox location, and, in some cases, the path to the Netscape installation.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: /usr/bin/mail Application for Sun Solaris Lets Local Users Gain Privileges of the Mail Group
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the mail client application that lets local users obtain effective group id privileges of the "mail" group.
The vulnerability is reportedly due to a buffer overflow in SunOS 5.8 x86 with $HOME and /usr/bin/mail.

If the user's HOME environment variable is set to a lengthy string, the vulnerability can be triggered.  The following setting will reportedly trigger the vulnerability:

HOME=`perl -e 'print "A"x1100'` ; export HOME
mail a
CTL-C

A demonstration exploit script is included in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user can obtain group id privileges of the "mail" user group.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.
Underlying OS Comments: SunOS 5.8 x86; other operating systems not tested

Title: Microsoft Hotmail May Allow a Worm to Send Mail to Other Destinations Listed in a Remote User's Inbox
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in Microsoft Hotmail that reportedly makes it possible for a remote user to send e-mail to a recipient containing Javascript code in a link that will be executed if the link is clicked. The Javascript code could then automatically send mail to all of the destinations listed in the recipient's inbox without user intervention. 
To trigger the cross-site scripting vulnerability, a remote user can send an e-mail message to the target recipient, where the e-mail contains a link to Microsoft's own server.  If the link contains escaped Javascript, it will be executed when the recipient clicks on the link (this is a requirement). That javascript could then open a window on the recipient's browser that could nagivate through the recipient's inbox, sending messages to all e-mail addresses listed in the recipient's inbox. Because the malicious javascript code is executing inside a page from the mail service's own server, there will reportedly be no domain-bounding error when the javascript is controlling the window with the victim's inbox.

Some sample links and the worm code are available at: 
http://www.sidesport.com/webworm/

The vendor was reportedly notified (note that the vendor responded publicly that it was *not* originally notified of this, but is now aware of the report and is investigating.
Impact': A remote user could send e-mail containing Javascript code that, when clicked by the Hotmail recipient, will send out e-mail to all addresses listed in the recipient's inbox.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (More Exploit Methods Described) Re: Eudora E-mail Client May Silently Install and Execute Malicious Trojan Software
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in Qualcomm's Eudora e-mail client that allows malicious trojan code to be installed and executed automatically and without warning by an unwitting recipient when the e-mail is read.
The author of the original report has supplied additional methods of performing silent delivery and installation of an executable on a target computer using the default installation of the mail client Eudora 5.1.  Read the Source Message for details.
Impact': An unsuspectig Eudora e-mail client user may inadvertently cause malicious trojan software to be installed and executed by reading a malicious e-mail message.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the report suggests disabling "use Microsoft viewer" and "allow executables in HTML content."

Title: Sun Solaris Mailtool Allows Local Users to Execute Arbitrary Commands on the Host with the Mail Group Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): Solaris 8 x86, Solaris 8 sparc, [possibly others]; 2.6 is reported vulnerable by another user
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the Solaris mailtool e-mail utility that allows local users to execute arbitrary commands with the "mail" group id privileges.
A buffer overflow reportedly exists in the OPENWINHOME environment variable. By supplying a long environment buffer containing machine executable code, a local user can execute arbitrary command(s).  Because the mailtool utility is installed with set group id "mail" privileges by default in Solaris, the arbitrary commands will be executed with "mail" group privileges.

This vulnerability has reportedbly been assigned Sun Bug ID: 4458476
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary commands on the server with "mail" group privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The advisory reports that users can clear the sgid bit off the /usr/openwin/bin/mailtool program as a workaround.

Title: Becky! Internet Mail Client May Allow Remote Users to Cause Arbitrary Commands to Be Executed By the Client
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the Becky! Internet Mail e-mail client software.  Successful exploitation of this vulnerability could allow remote attackers to cause arbitrary commands to be executed by the client.
It is reported that if an e-mail message includes more than 65536 bytes without any new line characters, a buffer will overflow. A buffer overflow also occurs when the user attempts to reply to or forward a message that includes over 8188 bytes without new line characters.

Successful exploitation of this vulnerability could allow remote attackers to cause the client to execute arbitrary commands.
Impact': A remote user could send a certain e-mail message that, when replied to or forwarded, will cause arbitrary commands to be executed by the client.
Solution: The vendor has released a new version.  See the Vendor URL to download the new version (2.00.06

Title: IncrediMail E-mail Client Allows Remote Users to Overwrite Files on the Host
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the IncrediMail e-mail system that allows remote users to send e-mail that will cause files to be overwritten on the IncrediMail recipient's host.
It is reported that, when sending mail or create a web page, a remote user can specify the filename of the skin, notifyer, animation etc. via a text file called Content.ini, which is found in the compressed skin or animation.  If the user applies ".." strings to the filename, the recipient's IncrediMail e-mail application can be fooled into using another filename to write to.  The Content.ini file is apparently automatically downloaded and copied to the client host when the client accesses a site or e-mail message that contains a download for the IncrediMail file.  If the file already exists, it will be overwritten.

A demonstration exploit example is provided at the following URL:

http://irc.m0ss.com/eos/advisories/incredimailexploit

This demonstration exploit example will reportedly create a file named Obscure.dat on the partition where you have installed IncrediMail.
Impact': A remote user can send e-mail or create a web page that will cause files to be overwritten on the IncrediMail recipient's host.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Exploit Code) Re: Mailx Client for Sun Solaris Allows Local Users to Execute Code with Mail Group Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Solaris mailx(1) client, allowing a local user to execute arbitrary code on the host with mail group privileges.
There is reportedly a buffer overflow vulnerability using the mailx -F option.  By specifying a long buffer containing machine executable code, it is possible for a local user to trigger the vulnerablity and cause an arbitrary command to be executed.  Because the mailx program is installed set group id mail by default in Solaris, this arbitrary code can be executed with mail group privileges.

The following packages/systems are reported to be vulnerable.

Solaris 8     SPARC
Solaris 8     x86
Solaris 7     SPARC
Solaris 7     x86
Solaris 2.6   SPARC
Solaris 2.6   x86
Solaris 2.5.1 SPARC
Solaris 2.5.1 x86
Solaris 2.5   SPARC
Solaris 2.5   x86

The vendor has reportedly been notified.

Some demonstration exploit code is contained in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can cause arbitrary code to be executed on the host with the mail group privileges.
Solution: The vendor is working on a patch.  In the meantime, it is suggested that users can clear the sgid bit of /usr/bin/mailx program.
